Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the Topology Students Workshop (TSW) held at the Georgia Institute of Technology during June 4-8, 2018. This is a five-day research and professional development workshop for graduate students in the fields of geometric group theory, geometry, and topology, designed to expose them to a wide range of current research, and to help build their communication, networking, and problem-sharing skills. Approximately sixty students will participate, guided by ten mentors, who come from a wide range of career stages and research backgrounds within this field. The conference provides essential training for the next generation of scientists, giving the participants many tools that will help them to succeed as scientists at the highest levels in graduate school and beyond. The professional development and research sides of the workshop run in tandem, with mentors giving guidance in both areas. The workshop emphasizes important career skills for mathematicians that are typically not taught in graduate school, including networking and etiquette, the job and grant application process, effective communication and research skills, and a panel discussion on career paths. The guidance is intended to be particularly beneficial to students from underrepresented groups.

Mathematical topics presented at TSW will cover a broad range within geometry and topology, including contact and symplectic topology, three-manifolds, hyperbolic geometry, group actions, and complex dynamics. The research talks will model good communication and will also introduce research areas and relevant problems to students who are embarking on a research career. For many of the students, the TSW is the first conference at which they are presenting their own results; the workshop is designed to facilitate this experience. For instance, the first professional development session is an introduction to conferences and how best to benefit from them. The goal is to build confidence and research potential among students. The skills addressed here can be especially beneficial to students from minority groups, as indicated from responses from participants in previous iterations of the program. The panel discussion on career paths involves mathematicians from organizations such as NSA, Amazon, Google, and private high schools. Effective communication is a major theme: two evening sessions are devoted to workshop presentations in small groups; the final presentations are videotaped and critiqued by those in attendance. The web site for the conference is http://tsw.gatech.edu.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Topology Students Workshop served as both a research conference and a professional development workshop for graduate students in the fields of geometric group theory, geometry, and topology. The workshop included 50 participants and 10 mentors at various career stages. The Topology Students Workshop is unique in its emphasis on community building, professional development, and communication skills. The conference, and its three predecessors, have been highly successful, as measured by direct feedback from the participants, their advisors, and the speakers/mentors at the conferences.  Several participants have described the workshop as life changing, and in many cases it has encouraged participants to continue to pursue a role in academia.  In the recruitment and admissions process, there is a heavy emphasis on diversity and inclusion.

The main goals of the Topology Students Workshop are (1) to provide training to graduate students on practical aspects of succeeding in academia, (2) To build research connections among junior researchers in fields related to topology, (3) to train graduate students to effectively communicate their research, (4) to demystify the processes behind job applications and publishing, and (5) to prepare graduate students for their careers after graduate school.  The Topology Students Workshop has furthered these goals by holding workshops on various professional development topics such as etiquette in academia, creating and delivering research presentations, writing effective CVs, navigating the job process in and out of academia, using relevant technical software, and the publishing process.  A heavy emphasis was placed on communication skills, and ample time was given for the participants to help each other workshop their presentations and receive feedback from mentors.
